content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are very careful and tend to avoid risks. You prefer to take a conservative approach and avoid uncertainties. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

Given my preference for a conservative approach and avoiding risks, I would choose to play it safe by consistently picking 'B' over 'R'. The reason behind this is that even though choosing 'R' yields a higher payoff when my opponent chooses 'B', the possibility of my opponent also picking 'R' and me receiving nothing is too risky for me.

In this game, the best strategy to maximize my expected earnings would be to choose 'R' if I believe my opponent will always pick 'B'. However, since I don't know their strategy, it's safer for me to assume they might also choose 'R'. By consistently choosing 'B', I guarantee a lower but stable payout of 20$ per round. In the worst-case scenario where both of us pick 'B', we each earn 20$.

If my opponent follows the same line of thinking, then it's likely that they will also choose 'B', making this strategy more effective and giving me a higher average payout over the course of 75 rounds. So, I would choose {B} for this game.
